This can be simplified dramatically. You don't need a setUp() at all if you inherit from _IntegratedTestBase. However that will force you to introduce a conditional around the CastAsCall fixture in that class. We can't use that fixture here because it will transform the instance stop cast into a call, and that will time out. So just have a class-level variable, call it CAST_AS_CALL or similar, default it to True, and wrap the use of the CastAsCall fixture in it. The in here, you just set it to False in the class.

we are not ment to be usnig _IntegratedTestBase any more for new test and regression test espically should not use it 


https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/tests/functional/regressions/README.rst#writing-regression-tests=

"""These should be full stack tests which inherit from nova.test.TestCase directly. (This is to prevent coupling with other tests)."""

While I agree with the goal to keep regression tests independent as they are backported a lot, I don't feel this is a hard rule. Also I'm not sure that _IntegratedTestBase makes it that much harder to backport a test. I think the most benefits are coming from having a separate file and separate base class.

As the test are currently written with the mixin class I think we should keep it. But I would not block on a regression test that is based on the _IntegratedTestBase either.

I would say this is ok, because I don't think in this case I've ever done anything but something ~ "git rebase --abort; git fetch -a; git rebase -i origin/<branch, usually master>" and merged things directly like that.

Unpacking those three commands for someone who a priori didn't know anything about git would probably take about a full day of tutorials and explanation about branches, rebases, staging commits, etc. :/ But I don't think that's really git-review's fault.

If you really don't know what's happening, resetting it so you can work your way through understanding the rebase process seems a good idea (at least you can follow tutorials, etc.).  If you do know what's happening, I imagine most like myself abort it and pull in changes manually anyway, because they want an up-to-date tree locally.  So ++ on the behaviour

I'm ok with this behavior change as a user since I almost always `git rebase --abort` in this situation myself. However, I think the reason to keep it may be if other users are less comfortable starting a new rebase by hand, but are comfortable completing the one that git review starts for you.

base/linuxptp/centos/patches/0007-phc2sy.message: See comments on the debian version of this patch

You're not preserving the original author and dates.  One way to do it:

git format-patch the original commit in its repo (or otherwise obtain it via your favourite means).  git am it into yours.  It will fail to apply.  Use the patch command (eg. show the diff that failed | patch -p1) and possibly the wiggle command to deal with rejects, and hand edit where needed (in your specific case here where you have already done the work, just replace the one file with yours).  Once the source is good, git add it then git am --continue.  Then git commit --amend adding your editorial and then generate the patch using git format-patch -s

Please do not directly edit patch files.  Such shortcuts often lead to other problems with the patch.

[ commit <commit-id> upstream ]

base/linuxptp/debian/patches/0007-phc2sy.message:
Unless you're making radical changes to the upstream commit, which you're not, you should completely preserve the entire original commit header including author.  Add your signature to it. eg:

[ commit e8dc364f9fd5fbdac5d2c5e433f28e9da0028d49 upstream

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_firewall/d.message:
I'm just curious but is this necessary ? For icmp I'm not aware of stateful connection and I thought just allowing new works. Actually the rule for ipv4 icmp does not have this so only accepts new. I have not clear idea what would be the difference between ipv4 icmp and ipv6 icmp requiring this.

This question might be dumb and just revealing I'm not familiar with networking, though. X-(

Ah, thanks. I was curious about the difference between v4 and v6. As long as this was added based on the test result then I'm totally ok.

I'm found the discussions in debian ml which is discussing the same problem, so will leave links here just as (my personal) note, 

https://lists.debian.org/debian-user/2016/10/msg00329.html
https://lists.debian.org/debian-user/2016/10/msg00331.html
https://lists.debian.org/debian-user/2016/10/msg00340.html

Yep, it's something we need to get. There are other status for that specific proto. At least, I could see dropped packets while doing tests in the fs035 testproject and, since it's now able to deploy the OC with mixed ipv6/ipv4 networks, I really suspect it was failing because of this specific missing line.

For the records, current iptables is dropping only "new" connections, while the new nftables setup drops *all* things that don't match a specific rule in the chain.

Also, icmpv6 is part of the protocol for ipv6 autoconfiguration - this isn't the case for the icmpv4.

Does it answer your question? I'm no ipv6 guru - so those are mostly the empirical knowledge I'm gathering while working on the issue ^^'.

And reference DIB_YUM_MINIMAL_BOOTSTRAP_REPOS logic to backup and recover regular mirrors like below. If users want to set another mirror when there is none.

 # install the bootstrap mirror repos over the default ones, if

 ..

proxysql_backend_max_connections >>

Well, your question is same as if I will ask you why mariadb has default max_connections = 10000 [0].

Moreover, mariadb has this hardcoded in it's template.


[0] https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/3f8683ccccaa44b836b5a158efe7183a4c572610/ansible/roles/mariadb/templates/galera.cnf.j2#L45

proxysql_max_connections >>

This is an hypotetical assumption that proxysql can be used with several mariadb shards/clusters which will have approx same load, so it's set to 40000 which means 4 * 10000.



proxysql_max_connections  ->   User -> ProxySQL VIP
proxysql_backend_max_connections ->   ProxySQL - Mariadb backend

And, it's also based on real deployment which we already have.

( shard1 - neutron
  shard2 - nova
  shard3 - everything else
)

I didn't want to include this long command inside config.json. And I also followed haproxy - as haproxy has it implemented in same way.


root@controller0:/home/ubuntu# cat /etc/kolla/haproxy/config.json 
{
    "command": "/etc/haproxy/haproxy_run.sh",
    "config_files": [




(haproxy)[root@controller0 /]# cat /etc/haproxy/haproxy_run.sh
#!/bin/bash -x

# We need to run haproxy with one `-f` for each service, because including an
# entire config directory was not a feature until version 1.7 of HAProxy.
# So, append "-f $cfg" to the haproxy command for each service file.
# This will run haproxy_cmd *exactly once*.
find /etc/haproxy/services.d/ -mindepth 1 -print0 | \
    xargs -0 -Icfg echo -f cfg | \
    xargs /usr/sbin/haproxy -W -db -p /run/haproxy.pid -f /etc/haproxy/haproxy.cfg

Considering the options are parsed with argparse lib, we shouldn't use underscore, but `-` instead, so `--vnf-id` and `--mark-delete`.

I don't understand why `--mark-delete` is diversified to `--mark-delete-v1` and `--mark-delete-v2`, and it takes `<vnf-id>` although it's already given with `--vnf-id`.

Is that enough as below?, In this case, the default target api ver is v1 as in the default case, and give v2 with `--api-ver` if the target is v2.

```
# default
tacker-db-manage migrate-to-v2 --mark-delete --vnf-id <vnf-id>

# give api-ver
tacker-db-manage migrate-to-v2 --mark-delete --api-ver v2 --vnf-id <vnf-id>
```
The command was modified. Please check.
This `--api-ver` takes only `v2` and doesn't `v1`, or just missing?

The difference between default and non-default values is just skipping to give the option `--api-ver` with the default value `v1`. So `v1` should also be described as an argument in the definition anyway in this case. My point is we should allow `--api-ver v1`, but it cannot be allow if you define only `--api-ver v2` which means the option `--api-ver` only accept `v2` and not for `v1`.

This test is still failing as follows:

AssertionError: assert 'Member services: nova/test-0.example.test@EXAMPLE.TEST, nova/dummy.example.test@EXAMPLE.TEST' in '  Role name: Nova Host Manager\n  Description: Nova Host Manager\n  Privileges: Nova Host Management\n  Member services: nova/dummy.example.test@EXAMPLE.TEST'

This is concerning.  We need to make sure the new code is doing the right thing.

So, the reason behind this change is this.

We were getting errors like: 

AssertionError: assert 'record: overcloud-novacompute-0.internalapi' in '  Record name: PTR record: overcloud-novacompute-0.ooo.test., overcloud-novacompute-0.internalapi.ooo.test.\n----------------------------\nNumber of entries returned 1\n----------------------------'

This is happening because we're adding duplicate entries for different IP addresses.   In this case pointed to above, we set 

172.17.0.110 overcloud-novacompute-0
172.17.0.110 overcloud-novacompute-0.internalapi

which leads to the results above.  There are others too - for the controller for instance.  I'm not entirely sure what changed to make this test fail - maybe the format of the DNS output.

This code change will allow the tests to pass - but maybe the right answer is to check the IPs that we are using in the tests and make sure that are no duplicates instead.
It also doesn't make sense to have a PTR record pointing to 2 domain names, so this should be one entry, overwritten with the latest one.
"Number of entries returned 1" - this doesn't look right, I would expect 2 entries.

What if the mocking gets contained to a "with" block so it automatically goes out of scope?

I think I figured out what's going on here. I don't think there's a bug in unittest.mock -- I think the problem is that the fixtures library will prefer to use the third-party mock library if it is present [1]:

  mock = extras.try_imports(['mock', 'unittest.mock'], None)

so when this test does fixtures.MockPatch, it will use the third-party mock library and set up the mocks there. And so mock.patch.stopall() calls unittest.mock's stopall method which will contain no mocks to stop.

Even though this patch replaces "import mock" with "import unittest.mock", all of our uses of mocks from the fixtures library will still be using the third-party mock library, which is a problem.

The third-party mock library is part of global-requirements [2], so AFAIK we can't stop fixtures from using third-party mock until we remove the global requirement.

[1] https://github.com/testing-cabal/fixtures/blob/20bf99299955dd7152538fd23ea3b6fd95a87f65/fixtures/_fixtures/mockpatch.py#L22
[2] https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/30109be02aec75349c502e98417deea9c2806846/global-requirements.txt#L403

Yeah, exactly. There's a bug in the version of unittest.mock on Python 3.6 (I think?) where stopall basically doesn't work. I tried to workaround this but didn't get anywhere. You can confirm by importing 'nova.objects.AggregateList.get_by_host' and checking the type. It'll still be a mock after this.
Here too.

It because of the weird thing we're doing below. You'll note that we use `mock.patch.stop`. This will now call `unittest.mock`, not `mock`. However, [fixtures uses `mock`](https://github.com/testing-cabal/fixtures/pull/49) which means this call doesn't "stop" anything. I'll call this out in the commit message.

Why do you think it isn't testing the relevant fix? It fails without the fix and passes with it.

The goal of this test is to raise an exception during a recv() which will interrupt the code path leading to the NovaProxyRequestHandler.new_websocket_client call when a request comes into the top-level of the server (simulated by calling WebSockifyServer.top_new_client). NovaProxyRequestHandler.new_websocket_client is where we create the nova.compute.rpcapi.ComputeAPI object upon access and when I raise a socket.error from recv() it will prevent NovaProxyRequestHandler.new_websocket_client from being called and then we verify that a nova.compute.rpcapi.ComputeAPI object was not constructed.

etc/policy.json.message:
This needs to be discussed on the spec.  The equivalent to show_multiple_locations=False would be "!", not "role:admin".

Also, in most places, if show_multiple_locations=False, the get_ and set_ never come into play.  These need to have the same value set as delete_ does (or, we need an explanation on the spec as to why not).

All the three can have same values only if all are left open in code. 
We cannot do "role:admin" for all the three location rules due to other projects depending on the current policy rules.
For example, if we had admin only for all 3 uploading image data would fail as that is not admin only.
Also tempest tests check locations after image creation, meaning we cannot set get_image_locations to admin only.
However, I felt that delete_image_locations is a crucial rule and can be admin only. We can diuscuss that on the spec maybe? I will leave this as is for now.

This is exactly why we need a spec.  The spec will have to map out what currently happens for various combinations of the show_multiple_locations option and the three policies.  Right now, we leave "set_image_location":"" and we can allow "upload_image":"", and end users can upload images but cannot set locations themselves when show_multiple_locations=False.  We are going to need to be able to preserve that behavior (i.e., end user can upload image data but cannot set locations manually) after show_multiple_locations is removed.

Also, if get_image_location is restricted, does that affect the current show_direct_url setting?  That's another complication that we'll have to deal with.

Since we are removing "show_multiple_locations", we now will have to proceed with policy rule checks. This means that to set an image location, all is needed is permission in the policy.json file (member role or admin role any role).In short, we will be relying on the policy rule to allow any image location actions.

Since uploading image data automatically sets an image location, it is necessary that "add_image" and "set_image_location" rules match. Which also means "get_image_location" match.
While we were using the config option "show_multiple_locations", we were preventing further location updates (subsequent location adds, removals, replacements) if show_multiple_locations was set to False.
Now since we are getting rid of it and relying in policies, it means that  subsequent location updates will also be permitted for the same user. I am thinking how we can achieve what the config option was doing.. It was only preventing subsequent location updates.. 

And answering to your final question, if get_image_location is restricted, yes what show_direct_url does will also be effected. As this relies on the policy "get_image_location" to decide whether and which (when there are multiple locations; it uses location_strategy) location to show.

I made it accept action as I thought hardcoding the action might not be the best idea. But since this is the response serializer, i think we can be fairly confident that the action will be 'get_image_location'. Will update it in the upcoming PS..

 >>> formatdate(S3Timestamp.now())
 'Tue, 26 Jul 2022 04:49:15 -0000'

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I tested with my vsaio, this MR fixed the S3Timestamp type errors.
Probably better to fix our Timestamp class.

The more I think about it, we probably *shouldn't* update Timestamp. The __index__() method is for

> losslessly convert[ing] the numeric object to an integer object

and implementing it for Timestamp would require the loss of sub-second resolution, so it's totally appropriate that we don't implement it (similar to float or Decimal or Fraction).

This introduces an optional config value, which default is the original behaviour, so this is OK from stable policy point of view. Besides, the patch is a clean cherry pick from master where the patch has merged. LGTM.

I think this may be testing more the get_share_export_locations method than the listing itself. I believe this assert could be dropped and we could keep only the assert below, that checks the result for the export location list command using the listing_result function.

This list is going to be recalculated for every item in the share_export_locations list. I think we can optimize this and declare this list outside, making it to be declared only once. The code starting from line 172 would look like:

    export_location_ids = [el['ID'] for el in share_export_locations]
        for share_export in result_export_locations:
            self.assertIn(share_export["ID"], export_location_ids)

releasenotes/notes/deprecate-flavorid-61.message:
my two cents:-

While checking other release notes for deprecations(in heat project) generally we add following sections:-

- deprecations
- upgrade (where needed)


for ex:
https://github.com/openstack/heat/blob/master/releasenotes/notes/deprecate-json-formatted-policy-file-ac2f98b31ece0baf.yaml

In my humble opinion, we should those two here instead of 'issues'


I found this interesting, where to use what section in release notes:-

* https://docs.openstack.org/reno/2.1.1/usage.html#editing-a-release-note

~~~
issues
A list of known issues in the release. For example, if a new driver is experimental or known to not work in some cases, it should be mentioned here.


upgrade
A list of upgrade notes in the release. For example, if a database schema alteration is needed.


deprecations
A list of features, APIs, configuration options to be deprecated in the release. Deprecations should not be used for something that is removed in the release, use upgrade section instead. Deprecation should allow time for users to make necessary changes for the removal to happen in a future release.
~~~

Yeah, good point. I changed it to deprecated now. There should be no impact on upgrades since the flavor.id they used will be the resource_id of the existing resources. I added a note about that in the upgrades section.

As mentioned earlier it does not matter to end users whether we use openstacksdk or python-novaclient. We should just mention that we're deprecating flavor_id property as it has very little significance.

swift/common/middleware/slo.py.message: I don't understand. As much as I can read RFC-7233, Section 2.1 says that bytes=-1 means "last byte of the representation". So, you receive a body of 1 byte long. And here we're trying to load the JSON of it. How does this work?

Yeah, that update_ignore_range_header() is tricky -- and we might still want to check that Content-Length is >1, in case the object-server that responds is from before https://github.com/openstack/swift/commit/e8b654f3 (i.e. prior to swift 2.24.0). If we *did* get back a single byte, we could refetch and fall back to the parent patch's behavior.

OTOH, our recommendation is to upgrade object-servers before proxies and the fallback is a fairly clean 500 which the client can/should retry. *shrug*

Not so bad fixing the upgrade bug. Might still consume a bunch of resources discarding if we've got

* replica A with an SLO manifest running swift <2.24.0 and
* replica B with a multi-gig non-manifest

but it's not any worse than what's already on master, and it should be a transient state as the upgrade progresses.

Note that using `resp.body` will ensure we read and close the bad response, so we don't need to add another drain_and_close() call here.

this all seems reasonable, but i'm not sure how big of a problem it is "if you configure it wrong it doesn't work right"

I guess reconstructor doesn't have a handoff_delete because a data frag revert always goes to the node index matching the frag index.  ec tombstones are more like replication, but they're kind of a special case:  https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/obj/reconstructor.py#L1261-L1266

The thing that pushed me over toward addressing it is a situation like

* policy A, 4 replicas
* policy B, 2 replicas
* handoff_delete = 3

On master, it all works as expected for policy A -- but policy B can't delete rebalanced data at all.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_podman/var.message:
have the feeling this should be autogenerated - especially to avoid any id conflict at some point.

Shouldn't we call podman to actually create the network, instead of pushing a static file?

Hello Cedric,

Thank you for your feedback, I was also sceptical about adding id here initially but I have considered the below points:-

* We are only creating a podman0 network if podman0 doesn't exist:
https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-ansible/+/845107/6/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_podman/tasks/tripleo_podman_install.yml#86

* For the CNI case as well we are also currently using default static network config[0] (but no hardcoded network id here in the config file)

* Based on discussion at [1], I came to know that by default the network config is stored in memory for netavark but you can create a config file at /etc/containers/networks/podman.json (default path, can be changed in containers.conf). Podman will use this file over the built-in default.

To change something(for example to add MTU) we have to run `podman network inspect podman | jq .[]` and then add the options block with the MTU to it and write it to the config file.

This seems an overkill to update at a later stage instead of providing network config for podman right from start. Because we have defined a var tripleo_podman_default_network_config we should allow users to override it if they want.

* Without id in /etc/containers/networks/podman.json - podman netavark complains. 

reproducer step: Create a network file /etc/containers/networks/podman.json without id and below warning will appear:-
~~~
WARN[0000] Error reading network config file "/etc/containers/networks/podman.json": json: cannot unmarshal array into Go value of type types. Network 
~~~

* The id which I have mentioned here is the default id which every podman0 network gets for netavark, looks like this id is hardcoded in netavark - we get the same id every time (so far based on my tests), On a new lab[2]

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-ansible/src/branch/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_podman/defaults/main.yml#L38-L61
[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2091840#c2

[2] 
~~~
# podman network ls
NETWORK ID    NAME        DRIVER
2f259bab93aa  podman      bridge

# podman network inspect 2f259bab93aa
[
     {
          "name": "podman",
          "id": "2f259bab93aaaaa2542ba43ef33eb990d0999ee1b9924b557b7be53c0b7a1bb9",
          "driver": "bridge",
          "network_interface": "podman0",
          "created": "2022-06-24T05:36:24.859103364-04:00",
          "subnets": [
               {
                    "subnet": "10.88.0.0/16",
                    "gateway": "10.88.0.1"
               }
          ],
          "ipv6_enabled": false,
          "internal": false,
          "dns_enabled": false,
          "ipam_options": {
               "driver": "host-local"
          }
     }
]

~~~


Please let me know your thoughts on this, The use case which we are trying to fix is we want a way to update `MTU` in podman netavark for the downstream case. (infra provides 1450 and by default, we get 1500 on the podman network).

swift/container/replicator.py.message: hmmm, pass or let it raise? do we ever expect to get here if there are no local device ids?

I figure pass as this will just make it return None, ie no node, and we catch it back in the sharder. Although I guess we could just as easily catch the IndexError in the sharder.. though that might be less counter intuitive.

If this method returns a node == None means we couldn't find a local handoff, which is true in this case right?

my concern is that we obscure a coding error - we should never get an IndexError (I think?), but if we catch it and then raise DeviceUnavailable we have obscured the bug

in fact, we're going to a lot of effort to annotate the exception message as if the problem might be specific to a partition, but in fact the problem is "_local_device_ids is empty, how can that be!?!"

ok, this method is also used to place reconciler container DBs. The locations of these are stored and then explicitly replicated at end of the replication cycle so it's OK for them to be on zero-weight devices.

that didn't work out quite as nicely as I had hoped - I had hoped we could have find_local_handoff_for_part just raise the exception and not have a try/except here - but I guess there is the customised exception message to deal with.

This is now more lines of code than the last version for the same outcome :/

But as commented above, maybe there is no value in annotating the exception - it's going to be raised for *every* partition that we try to get a handoff for.

...do we have to (re)raise DeviceUnavailable here? It's not clearly valuable to me. I kind of want to just get rid of the if block (or try/except block) and let the context of "we hit this problem while trying to create a handoff reconciler broker" be passed along by the fact that there was a get_reconciler_broker frame in the stack.

I made this a warning because we do not expect it to happen often and if it does an op might like a clue as to why DBs are appearing on a zero weight node.

opinions?

yeah, we do pass in the node when we start processing a db, but not when we get to cleave. I started out by trying to plumb it through, but started to seem like alot of churn. When we already store the local dev ids.

I figured might as well make it random one in case we're draining for a reason.. seemed safer. But yeah, needing to go searching is annoyting, but at least we're only doing if we can't get a local handoff from the replica2part2dev table.

ok! that switch to a dict wasn't too disruptive :)

I wonder if this fallback behavior should go up in find_local_handoff_for_part() -- we can run into the same problem feeding the reconciler queue, too, right?

I guess the good news is, if we popped a similar error there, we've got a catch-all to log it, but then we'll proceed to cleanup: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/2.29.1/swift/common/db_replicator.py#L686-L692

In fact, I wonder if it'd be better for find_local_handoff_for_part() to check whether we've got a local primary disk, then immediately fall back to a random local device. If we've got hundreds of A/C disks, IDK that it's worth potentially going through the whole list just to get a node that's closer to being accessible to a proxy.

Yeah, I like the idea of moving it back into find_local_handoff_for_part.

Got think some more the if a node doesn't have a primary disk just return a random local disk. This could reduce our loops, but it's only part_nodes more. And having it within proxies reach for a partition does sound like a good and expected thing.. a random disk would loose this nice trait.
Done

I think I'd be fine with blowing up harder here -- this should *never happen*, right? We need a local handoff because we're currently processing a DB we found on disk, and we would have added the disk this DB is on to the dict, right?
Done
Off-topic: It's kinda weird that we have to do this again here, instead of *only* populating it in db_replicator...
Ack
+1 I have also wondered why this is repeated - is there a subtle difference? but, different topic
nit: move this line after the 'if not node' check
Done

I think we could move the raise into find_local_handoff_for_part method - the other place it is called in replicator.py for reconciler containers the pattern is very similar - we might just need to pass in a string to customize the exception message.
oh yeah thanks very true. Moved it into the function too.

This is the only place we would handle the DeviceUnavailable specifically, yeah? Once we have this change, we would expect *every* shard range to blow up here if this is ever going to blow up, right? So everything's going to stall out anyway -- I kind of wonder if we should just let it bubble up to the general per-db exception handling in _one_shard_cycle...
Done
Right, so we still have the failure stat sometimes -- and now we always know what it means.
